description: From Middle English jolyfte, from Old French joliveté (“gaity, cheerfulness; amorous passion; life of pleasure”), from jolif. Equivalent to jolly +‎ -ty.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state of being jolly; jolliness, cheerfulness.
(countable) Revelry or festivity; a merry or festive gathering.
examples: Across the US, candidates traditionally attend rallies, barbecues and similar jollities in their states and districts.

entries.meaning: (countable) Things, remarks, or characteristics which are enjoyable.
